2.7. Protoplast preparation

Superior strains obtained from previous physical or chemical mu- tation and selected as parents for genome shuﬄing were grown sepa- rately in Erlenmeyer ﬂaks (250 mL) containing 50 mL of previously sterilized PDB, with incubation at 27 °C under 150 rpm orbital shaking for 72 h. S. oryzae biomass was ﬁltered through a sterile Miracloth. The mycelium was retained and washed with a sterilized 1 M NaCl solution until residual media and particularly S. oryzae conidia, macroconidia and blastospores were eliminated. Approximately 10 mg of wet myce- lium was transferred to a microtube containing 1.0 mL of a 10 mg/mL Trichoderma harzianum lytic enzyme (Sigma-Aldrich ®) solution pre- pared with sterilized 1 M NaCl. The microtubes were gently mixed, followed by incubation at 27 °C under 100 rpm orbital shaking. After four hours, the suspension was ﬁltered through sterile Miracloth. The suspension content was observed by optical microscopy using a Neubauer chamber (400 X magniﬁcation). The shape and number of protoplasts were evaluated ( supplementary ﬁle ).2.8. Genome shuﬄing The genome shuﬄing (GS) procedure used in this work was based on those of Cheng et al. (2009) and Wang et al. (2016) , with several simpliﬁcations as described in the next paragraphs. Eight superior mutant strains previously obtained through physical or chemical mu- tagenesis were selected as progenies for GS. The selection of exactly eight mutants was performed according to the studies of Sankoﬀ and Goldstein (1989) and Wang et al. (2016) on probabilistic models of GS. Protoplast suspensions of the eight progenies were individually adjusted to the same concentration (1.0 × 105protoplast/mL) with the addition of a sterilized 1 M NaCl solution when necessary. The proto- plasts of eight selected progenies were combined together (15.0 µL each) in a microtube. This procedure was repeated in three diﬀerent microtubes, two of which were subjected to deactivation under UV-C irradiation (15 W/265 nm/45 cm distance/10 min) and by heating at 50 °C (50 min). After the deactivation period, 880 µL of a solution containing 35% PEG 6000, 0.1% CaCl2 and 1 M NaCl was added to the microtubes, deactivated or not, followed by incubation at 27 °C for
40 min under 100 rpm orbital shaking. The protoplasts were re-

generated by spreading 100 µL of protoplast suspension in Petri dishes containing PDA supplemented with 1 M NaCl. The colonies were counted and isolated after seven days (slower growth) in Petri dishes with PDA and then incubated at 27 °C for 10 days. The mutant strains were duplicated on PDA. The mutant selection procedure described above was applied to identify the new superior strains (in comparison to the wild-type strain).

The GS procedure was repeated four times (four GS cycles or four sequential protoplast fusion rounds). For each new GS cycle, the eight new parents selected were the most superior mutant strains resulting from the previously GS procedure ( Fig. 1 b). All the GS mutant strains resulting from this process were named “GS”, plus a number from 1 to 4, representing the GS cycle, and were then numbered sequentially.

2.11. Virulence of S. Oryzae mutant strains

As noted above, S. oryzae is frequently associated with rice sheath rot disease. In an eﬀort to assess the virulence of the new S. oryzae mutant strains, the methodology described by Sakthivel et al. (2002) was used. 3.1. Parental library

TheSarocladium oryzae BRM 6461 wild-type strain exposed to mu- tagenic agents (UV-C irradiation or EMS) and sequential selection through conventional or high-throughput screening procedures gave rise to the parental library. The adjusted mutation method deﬁned the exposure period to each mutagenic agent, ensuring a maximum survival rate of 5% of cells, consequently increasing the probability that all survivors would be mutants ( Burnett, 1975 ; Kava et al., 1995). Positive mutants showed increased production of cerulenin or tolerance to UV-B irradiation or higher temperature. The process resulted in a total of 1932 mutant strains, among which 26 strains exhibited higher cer- ulenin production compared to the wild-type strain (cerulenin yield- positive mutant frequency = 1.34%), and 2 strains exhibited increased UV-B tolerance (UV-B tolerance-positive mutant frequency = 0.10%). However, the process did not generate strains with increased tolerance to high temperature.

The best improved-cerulenin-yield strains showed a production in- crease of approximately 15% compared to the wild-type strain, S. or- yzae BRM 6461. Moreover, the top 8 improved strains, selected as the parents for the genome shuﬄing procedure, presented cerulenin yields from 156.2 ± 1.6 µg/mL to 166.2 ± 3.1 µg/mL. Among these strain, M009 (UV-C) and M793 (EMS) stood out, exhibiting production of 166.2 ± 3.1 µg/mL and 165.1 ± 3.0 µg/mL, respectively ( Table 1 ). Another signiﬁcant observation was that both chemical (EMS) andphysical (UV-C) mutagenic agents produced improved-cerulenin-yield mutants, with positive frequencies of 2.46% (15 strains) and 1.40% (11 strains), respectively, making it impossible to diﬀerentiate which was the most eﬃcient for S. oryzae (Table 2 ). In fact, increasing the pro- duction rate of a secondary metabolite due to mutagenesis depends on the type of mutagenic agent and varies from species to species. This study showed similar results to those obtained by Luo et al. (2012) when producing a parent library for genome shuﬄing of Streptomyces gilvosporeus . Using chemical and physical mutagenic agents, they de- veloped strains exhibiting increases in secondary metabolite production varying from 18% to 22%, with a positive mutant frequency from 1.30% to 15.6% in comparison to the wild-type strain.

According to the results, the M103 and M419 mutants, both pro- duced using UV-C as a mutagenic agent, tolerated exposure to a total dosage of 7.0 kJ/m2UV-B irradiation more eﬃciently than the wild- type, with a UV-B tolerance-positive mutant frequency = 0.025%. However, these strains did not present stable UV-B irradiation tolerance over three generations of subcultivation. In addition, these strains failed to produce a higher cerulenin yield compared to the wild-type strain (data not shown). A plausible explanation may be related to the lack of melanin. According to Gao and Garcia-Pichel (2011) , physiologically, there is a relationship between melanin and the UV protection of pro- karyotic and eukaryotic organisms due to the ability of melanin to absorb UV irradiation, preventing DNA damage, causing it to be con- sidered a natural sunscreen. The production of melanin seems to be very low in Sarocladium oryzae , which is easily veriﬁed by the presence of hyaline conidia and white to light-yellow mycelial coloration ( Bills et al., 2004; Summerbell et al., 2011; Giraldo et al., 2015 ). The ﬁrst hypothesis to the low presence of melanin in S. oryzae cells is the presence of cerulenin, a melanogenesis inhibitor ( Kubo et al., 1986 ), produced by the own fungi. 3.2. Superior strains resulting from the genome shuﬄing (GS) process In this study, four cycles of GS resulted in the development of a superior cerulenin strain. The consecutive protoplast fusion of the top 8 parental mutant strains allowed a ﬁnal increase of 42% in cerulenin production, reaching a maximum of 203.3 ± 1.4 µg/mL. However, each GS cycle contributed diﬀerently to the observed genetic im- provement, with rates varying from 2.8% (fourth cycle) to 9.8% (ﬁrst cycle) ( Fig. 2 a and 2b). Table 2 shows that the positive mutant fre- quency resulting from GS was higher than that produced by the che- mical and physical mutagenic agents. Moreover, the positive mutant frequency always increased from the ﬁrst cycle (GS1) to the last cycle (GS4). The explanation is that GS technology always requires the use of genetically preconditioned cerulenin highly productive strains (parent strains). Shi et al. (2018) previously reported this phenomenon, which is observed in almost all genome shuﬄing studies. As shown in Fig. 2 c, the GS4-03 strain maintained cerulenin production during ﬁve succes- sive subcultivation assays. Consequently, the results indicated that the superior strain exhibited suﬃcient hereditary stability for futurecommercial/industrial applications.
3.3. Biocontrol of white mold and root rot diseases

The enhancement of the biocontrol power of S. oryzae , or any other BCA strain, is an interesting strategy for increasing the eﬃciency of the bioproduct and accelerating its commercial and industrial adoption. According to Guimarães et al. (2018) and Côrtes et al. (2014) , some S. oryzae strains act as BCAs due to their high antagonistic activity against widespread plant pathogens as a consequence of the production of cerulenin, an antifungal secondary metabolite. Up to this point in our study, the results showed that the designed pipeline was eﬃcient for developing a superior strain, S. oryzae GS4-03, with increased cerulenin production. However, the results below show the impact of increased cerulenin production on the biological control power of S. oryzae GS4- 03 compared to the wild-type strain.

Although the correlation between antagonism and biocontrol is not always positive, it is generally indicative of the biocontrol potential of a microbial strain. The ﬁrst assay consisted of in vitro antagonism chal- lenge between the S. oryzae GS4-03 and BRM 6461 strains against Rhizoctonia solani BRM 29,725 (Rs 144) and Sclerotinia sclerotiorum BRM 29,673 (Ss 12). The results showed that the GS4-03 strain pro- vided a statistically signiﬁcant increase in the mycelial inhibition of both pathogens compared to the wild-type strain ( Table 3 ). In addition, the GS4-03 strain abolished the production of sclerotia, an important resistance structure involved in pathogenesis produced by S. scler- otiorum .

This does not include biocontrol for postharvested ap- plication or the use of biomolecules. To the best of our knowledge, there are no full papers describing the use of this important tool to improve fungal BCAs. Consequently, this is the ﬁrst work demon- strating the eﬀect of genome shuﬄing on the improvement of fungal BCAs.

3.5. Biochemical analysis

The kinetic data of cerulenin production by GS4-03 is in accordance with Fig. 5 b. The kinetics of consumption of substrates and biomass production by the GS4-03 ( Fig. 5 a) and wild-type BRM 6461 strains (Fig. 5 b) cultivated in the optimized MP media presented a similarproﬁle. The production of cerulenin reached a higher level after 72 h of cultivation, with a volumetric productivity of Q p= 2.82 mg/Lh by the GS4-03 strain, in contrast to Q p= 1.99 mg/Lh by the wild-type strain BRM 6461 ( Table 6 ), representing a 42% increase. The consumption of glycerol presents a diﬀerent pattern throughout the strains. However, it is not possible to explain the diﬀerences in the production of cerulenin based on this information.

Another major concern related to the improvement of a certain phenotypic characteristic of a microbial strain is to cause damage in DNA regions responsible for another important function. For this reason, this study also evaluated the activity of three hydrolytic en- zymes (protease, chitinase and ß-1,3-glucanase) that are highly re- levant to general BCA activity ( Elad, 1996 ).Table 7 shows that hy- drolytic enzyme activities did not change as a consequence of mutagenesis procedures.
3.6. Genetic analysis of improved strain

Random ampliﬁed polymorphic DNA (RAPD) was the ﬁrst tech- nique used to detect and distinguish the genetic variation between the wild-type and improved strains, using the primers successfully devel- oped by Ayyadurai et al. (2005) to assess genetic variability in Sar- ocladium oryzae strains CAT, MR, GF and RY. However, only primers MR and GF produced PCR products. Genomic DNA from S. oryzae BRM 6461, M009, M793 and GS4-03 presented the same banding pattern (supplementary ﬁle ).

This result was unexpected for three main reasons: (a) primers CAT, MR, GF and RY were validated for the identiﬁcation of genetic varia- bility in S. oryzae strains, (b) wild-type and GS4-03 strain colonies ex- hibited visible morphological diﬀerences, and (c) the mutagenic agents used to prepare the parent library are known to be highly aggressive. The chemical mutagenic agent EMS induces diverse classes of base substitutions, with high predominance of GC to AT substitutions, and its mutagenic activity occurs in the absence of a DNA repair system (Coulondre and Miller, 1977 ). Moreover, UV-C light induces bulky predominantly GC to AT transitions but also induces all other types of base changes, frameshifts and deletions that are dependent on the DNA repair system ( Foster, 1991 ).

Furthermore, in a second attempt to detect genetic variation be- tween the studied strains, the ITS regions of both the wild-type and GS4-03 strains were ampliﬁed, sequenced and aligned ( supplementary ﬁle). The results showed 99.53% consensus, with three mutations at positions 516 (R to G), 606 (G to C), and 625 (G to C). With the same ITS data and GenBank data, the evolutionary history was inferred using the neighbor-joining method, and evolutionary distances were com- puted using the maximum composite likelihood method. The analysis involved six nucleotide sequences, and all positions containing gaps and missing data were eliminated. There was a total of 498 positions in the ﬁnal dataset ( supplementary ﬁle ). The results were expected, showing a short genetic distance between the sequenced ITS regions of the wild- type and superior strains.
3.7. Dual culture assay

We applied a simple test consisting of an antagonistic assay to detect genetic variability, whereas genetic analysis through DNA ampliﬁcation methods was not fully eﬃcient. Fig. 6 a and 6b show fusion between two colonies of the same wild-type BRM 6461 strain, mainly at the ex- tremities, demonstrating the compatibility between the colonies and consequently conﬁrming that they have the same genetic background. On the other hand, the antagonist culture between the improved strain GS4-03 and the wild-type strain resulted in a boundary line ( Fig. 6 c and 6d). These results indicate that these strains have diﬀerent genetic backgrounds and thus indicate that genome shuﬄing technology was eﬃcient for genetically improving the S. oryzae strain.

4. Conclusion

In this study, the designed pipeline for the genetic improvement of BCAs, based on GS technology, proved to be eﬃcient in producing a superior S. oryzae strain that is able to control root rot and white mold diseases more eﬃciently than the wild-type strain. Despite the high eﬃciency of modern technologies (ex. genetic engineering) in im- proving certain characteristics of microorganisms, they are generally more expensive, require previous knowledge of the genetic background and depend on regulatory approval compared to conventional methods. In addition, the platform can be adapted to other BCAs with some ad- justments, mainly in terms of the screening methods.
